This navigational control system is the most unintuitive and illogically designed system I have ever seen.  It takes too many steps to accomplish simple operations.  Nowhere can I find a display of the vehicle's speed, nor is there a resettable trip odometer connected to the GPS.  There is no excuse to block certain operations while the vehicle is moving; the passenger should have access to these operations.  The book says voice commands can be used; however, the cabin has to be very quiet, and you must know the exact words to say for the many commands or they won't work.  This system is so bad, it would have been a deal-breaker had I taken the time to explore it more.  The music/radio control system is only marginally less complicated to operate.  There is a manual on/off/volume knob on the left side, but noticeably missing is an equivalent manual tuning knob on the right side!  I cannot stress enough how overly complicated this system is to use.
(Copied from AEN97): one out of 5 attempts to call a person.  Wrong conZZZt pulls up.

(Copied from AEN97): First the main Navigation and audio screen faded almost to black even though it was still light outside and so it was useless (Could not be seen at all).  It was an intermittent problem and was corrected by my finding a Technical Service Bulletin online in a Buick Envision Owners' Forum and taking it to my dealer, who applied a software update.  A month later on one occasion, the screen was totally off and could not be turned on so I could not see radio stations, or any touch screen buttons.  It stayed that way for about 100 miles, at which time it went to ""blue screen"" full of computer code, although my driver info screen in the instrument panel still worked and could be used for turn-by-turn navigation via RRR.  I took a rest break at about the 150 mile mark, and when I started the vehicle after that stop, all returned to normal and has worked fine for the last 3 months.

Our other Cadillac doesn't do this, nor any other car we've owned.  I've went through the menus and called our sales rep, but there does not appear to be a fix for this.  I literally have to press and hold, then look at the display to see that it went to a station then release; which means every time i want to go to another preset station i have to take my eyes off the road.  Most people have to scroll through a multiple stations before they settle on one they like, so I think this is a terrible feature and a nuisance, to an otherwise car that i really enjoy.

(Copied from FCD97): I have two items I wish to note 1) Chime for passenger seat belt intermittently sounds.   I have not taken this to the dealer for correction, as I know it will not be fixed.   I leased a 2015 ATS, and now a 2018 ATS.   The problem existed also in the 2015 model.   Per the dealer, and additional investigation I completed with a friend who works for XX as an engineer at the proving grounds, I was told that this is a known problem and is not slated for correction/modification.   Basically what happens is if the passenger seat is unoccupied, and you place any small items that has metal  (namely sunglasses or the phone charging cable) on the seat, the sensor activates the chime.   It is an annoying chime that we now just ignore.   Although I will say that I almost did not get another Cadillac because of this, but the AWD availability and XX discount sucked me back in for a 2018 lease.2) Bluetooth connectivity for Spotify. actually, I had been in the car about 8 minutes.  The lights inside the car switched off about 6 minutes into my job. After a day or so, battery is charged, and no problems since.  I learned to use dome lights to eliminate that potential problem.  This was a problem in electronics, somehow.  8 minutes fumblilng in car should not wear down the battery!!!  I had nothing on, I was putting in a piece of Velcro and had drivers door open.

The AM radio is horrible. It constantly generates squeels and whistles near the bottom of the AM band. There are no other obvious RF signals that would otherwise cause this heterodyne effect. This radio seems to be of low quality and poor design as it does not discriminate against electromagnetic ingress interference.

The built-in navigation system is missing numerous locations (POIs) that have existed for many years. It is also missing lots of streets in my city that also have been there a while. As a result, I frequently switch to the GPS in my phone, since it has more current and more accurate data.

(Copied from AEN97): 1a. Every time my phone connects to the car's Bluetooth interface, it automatically starts playing whatever music/podcast/whatever was last played, even if the device is paused -- even if the app has been closed.  This is very frustrating.1b. Once I get it paused, the music/podcast/whatever starts up again between when I turn off the car and I open the driver's door because there is a brief connection interruption and re-connection; see #1a.2. There is no Pause button accessible from all screens and modes.  (Ideally, there should be a physical Pause button next to the steering wheel volume control buttons.)  The lack of a Pause button  makes #1 more frustrating because I must figure out which app is playing (see #1a), then start up that app via CarPlay or the phone to access the app's Pause button.  'Pause/Play' is a universal Bluetooth command -- my headphones implement it just fine and it works for all apps.  Why is there no universal Pause in the Chevy Infotainment interface?

I feel as if it has a mind of its own. I think the most common problem is when I pick up the iPhone to glance at it or change the music selection in stopped traffic, it sometimes won't play at all, even when I see the song progressing on the touchscreen. I realize this could be a volume issue, but it has happened so many times under so many circumstances, that I'm quite sure I'm either doing something terribly wrong, or the car and the phone are simply not made to play with each other.

There's no option for a front passenger to see what's playing on the screen unless the car is in park. Which means that when my husband is driving, and I want to start or select menu options for a DVD that is playing in the back for my toddler, I have to unbuckle and view the rear screen to know what I need to select on the front menu. The vehicle also AUTOMATICALLY starts random audio playing when the car is started or a phone is plugged in. Which means that when there's a DVD in the player that has been stopped, and I have used & shut off (which the car displays as muted) the radio since the DVD was stopped, and we get back in the car after lunch, it AUTOMATICALLY starts the DVD, which we can't see because the screen is up and we can't hear because the sound is muted. So we go to start the movie for the toddler where it was paused 2 hours ago on our road trip, only to find out its been playing on mute since the last stop & I have to unbuckle again and use the rear screen to adjust!

1. The touchscreen isn't responsive enough, so I often have to touch a different station 3-4 times before it switches.  2. (Copied from FCD97): 1. I do not want to hear the beeping when the car thinks I'm too close to an object. I've turned the option off TWICE, but every time I start the car it comes back on. 2. (Copied from AEN97): We bought the car in CA and drove it home to Seattle, WA. Often, the satellite radio goes out, does not come back, and we have to go to ""Radio"" then back to ""satellite"" to get service with the satellite radio.

There are two modes of operation: a quick-turn mode where you touch the stalk briefly and it indicates two or three times then stops, and a continual turn mode. The first of these is no problem, though I would prefer it indicate at least 4 times because two or three times isn't enough. The second mode is a more 'permanent' turn indicator position, where is clicks into position (up of down) and stays there. Unless the steering wheel rotates at least 180 degrees back, the stalk will not snap back into 'neutral', and I can't get it to go back. usually, I will attempt to snap it back into a neutral position but must hit it so hard it goes past neutral to the other indicating direction. I know, picking nits, but this is the only car I've had this problem with.
The between seat storage console is small, and the USB port in the rear of the console. It's not a perfect design.
Voice recogntion has suffered since my 2008 Honda Odyssey. Not sure why this works so poorly.
Voice command is not navigation friendly. XM RADIO is saved via numbers not names of station. Hard to remember all stations associated with station.

Presets are not arranged by band, so wishing to check FM presets, for instance, requires stepping over satellite presets.  There is no 'clear presets' function.  I think the arrangement is poor:  I think when a band (FM AM satellite) is selected, only related data should be displayed.  It shouldn't take two or three steps to get to tone and balance controls.

The ignition button is not clearly visible when I sit in the driver's seat and start the car. It is visibly blocked by the steering wheel and wiper blade mechanism. I believe this is due in part to my height. When the dealer salesman was demonstrating the vehicle for me, I had no idea what he was doing. Even sitting in the front passenger seat, it was difficult for me to see where the actual ignition button was located. I had never had a vehicle that used a key fob rather than an actual key, so, at first I was confused. Now, even though I do not see the ignition button, I know where it is located and can feel comfortable starting the car.

I told the sales rep that sold me the vehicle that the navigation was one of the most important features I was looking for in a new vehicle. I have had difficulty using Android Auto to sync my phone's map function to the screen.  I'm very upset about this and will look very closely before purchasing my next vehicle.  I may not purchase another Chevrolet if this functionality is not available in the future.

(Copied from AEN97): Bluetooth connection works great for phone calls, but it prevents other phone audio from being heard unless you are on the bluetooth device as the audio source. So, things such as verbal map directions via Google Maps or any non-native-phone app call/sound notifications are muted (these don't sound on phone, since the phone is connected to a bluetooth device). So when you take a long distance trip in the vehicle and need to be able to hear anything phone related, you either have to use your phone for music (makes the satellite radio useless) or disconnect the phone from the car's bluetooth (which makes the car's phone capabilities useless).

it's hard to get your USB and cigarette lighter plug into slot.  The coverings to the USB spot are in they way when you flip them open to use.  Maybe if you had a little snap that you could snap it back and it would stay open.  But the flap will flip back in the way if you don't hold it open.  And if you have a plug in the cigarette lighter, THEN you try and put something in the USB slot, it's even more difficult.  This is also due to the bottom of the actual dash, it sticks out slightly over the little cubby hole that the slots are in.  I think if you just angled the little slots towards the driver/ passenger, then it wouldn't be so bad.  I would also separate the cigarette lighter slot just a little more from the USB slots. One of the vehicle settings is for the Anti Theft system. It gives you the ability for the system to have full sensor arming 'ALL SENSORS' which would include interior motion sensors as well as perimeter sensors. You can choose from three settings as the default. All sensors, perimeter or ask on exit. The car remembers 'All Sensors' and 'ask on exit' but the perimeter selection is only good for one lock - unlock cycle. Why even bother having the prompt at all? It leads people to believe that you can have perimeter sensors set as a default so when you leave your dogs in the car they don't continually set the alarm off. I am not sure I would have bought the car if I had known ahead of time that I could not permanently set the alarm default to perimeter only. With out using the car for a week you would never realize how the system works. A bad piece of programming. Yes my dogs set the alarm off allot.

This was a tough one to diagnose, as it was intermittent.  Audio source (satellite radio, Apple Car Play) didn't seem to matter, nor did audio content (talk, music, heavy base, little base).  I first noticed this the day after taking delivery.  It was in the front passenger door.  It occurred once or twice per week for the first couple of weeks, by the time the car was 1 month old (1,500 miles) the rattle was a daily occurrence.  Usually started after approximately 10 minutes of starting the car and would last anywhere from 10 seconds to 2 minutes.  The dealer had my vehicle on 3 separate, multi-day occasions to try to resolve this issue (7-8 nights total).  After removing the door panel and replacing the broken interior trim fasteners on the back side of the door panel (I was told they replaced roughly 1/2 of the fasteners in each front door), and also replacing one of the passenger door speaker grills, the issue appears to be corrected.  Issue has been resolved for 2 weeks now.

Argh, where do I begin. The whole system is like playing a video game with ""3D"" graphical representation of things. For example, instead of a simple easy to read elapsed or remaining time indicator for a CD track, there is a thin glowing bar that creeps across the bottom of the screen. There is no display of full info for a track at the same time (e.g. album, track, artist, time, cover art, etc). The SiriusXM tuner only shows channel name when browsing, rather than currently playing artist/song (as other brands do). The SXM display does not scroll long song titles, they get cut off instead. The SXM ""favorites"" feature will switch from ""Presets"" mode to ""SXM"" mode if you play a ""favorite"" when the notice pops up. The 2017 PCM Navigation provides too little information. It just gives one piece of information such as ""drive on highway x for 2 miles"" but doesn't give any information on what to next until it, the GPS, thinks I need to know. Then, it's only by voice, not display.  It says ""prepare to turn right"" but there's no indication on the display. The GPS also does not say if the destination is on the right of left hand side until I've arrived which is too late. There is a ""list view"" option from the ""route"" menu but this is not integrated with the current map and detailed direction.  My Infiniti EX35 has a list view on half of the screen and current location and driving instruction on the other half of the screen.  This is ideal. The 2016 Macan manual also indicates it has this capability. In short, the GPS needs to provide more information in a more timely manner on the screen and by voice. Also, the some of the routes (turn list) are comical because they are so bad.

First, please understand that I am spoiled by Google Maps, Waze, and even Apple Maps (I use an iPhone).  The first issue is when sending a destination to my truck via My Chevrolet app.  When I use that method, the screen splits between navigation and media.  This split screen does not display all of the information I need that I would see on the full navigation screen.  When I put in a destination via the touchscreen, I get the full navigation results.  The second issue is that rerouting due to traffic either does not happen, or not quickly enough.  And it does not seem to take traffic into account before I start driving.  This second problem could be due to me being spoiled by other navigation sources as I mentioned before.  If Chevrolet adds the ability to use Google Maps and/or Waze via Apple Play, that would be amazing.  For now, I don't see myself using the truck's navigation unless I absolutely have to.

(Copied from FCD97): This is a feature, not a defect, but from my perspective is a design flaw that causes malfunction on this vehicle and the previous Kia Forte 5-door 2012 I owned. The controls for turning on/off/auto lights on the end of the blinker is sensitive to being turned inadvertently to a different setting when operating the blinker. So while I prefer to keep it set on 'on' sometimes without my knowledge, it gets turned to 'auto' or 'off'. That can be a problem if I do not realize I am driving with my lights off when I think they are on.

(Copied from AEN97): 1) The radio controls being on the right side of the steering are very annoying. These controls should be on the left side of the steering wheel to allow for better control of the audio system. (ala pre F01/2009 7 series design)  2) The rotary wheel for advancing music track selection should also allow for 'Previous' and 'Next' track. This makes Next track selection with the bluetooth/USB feature impossible with the steering wheel controls and the next track must be selected via the I-drive controller or ASK buttons.  3) The 'Previous' and 'Next' buttons for the audio system are on the very right side of the audio system control panel (ASK). This makes quick track stations very difficult without having to reach into the passenger's area. BMW's are supposed to have 'Driver-centric' controls and the placement of this switch in this location violates this premise.

The music pairing is terrible.  In my previous 2008 TL I would get in the car, turn it on, and the phone would pair, and the music would pick up right where I left off.  If I was listening to Pandora, or i-Tunes, on my headset, or had been listening to it in the car, the music would pickup right where I left off.  Now, the phone will connect but wont play.  In order to get it to play I have to disable and re-enable blue-tooth.  When using Pandora, there is a separate app built into the car that runs it.  This app requires to to 'Allow' pandora to play every time I start the car.  When I do enter the car, and the pairing works, the music that plays will vary randomly out of i-Tunes like its on shuffle everything, and will not come back from where I left off.  I am very upset with the way this has changed and don't understand how something that worked so well, got so messed up.

The MMI wheel is completely backwards and needs to be reversible in the settings. I don't know who decided that turning clockwise should ""open"" and counterclockwise should ""close"". This behavior is extremely annoying.  I spoke with my Audi service people who report hearing this same feedback from many other customers.  Switching between MMI and CarPlay is very unclean.  There needs to be a button that gets the driver directly back to CarPlay if one has to leave to another function. I recently had to switch the clock forward an hour for DST. Looked up ""clock"" in the 500 page (!) owner's manual index and turned to the indicated page. The instructions were brief, but only because they were not clear and omitted certain steps I was assumed to know. I especially resented having to use controls that served more than one function, but which were not obvious, such as pressing a button to select the hour function, but not knowing that the same button had to be pressed again to change the hour up or down. The menu has too many steps and is slow to respond. For example, if there are multiple versions of a street name, the navigation system displays a large banner message telling you to select one of the options, but that banner completely obscures the list of choices for several seconds, preventing you from making your selection until that banner message goes away. Since the driver knows he has to select from the list, this approach is completely unnecessary and overly time-consuming. Also, Lexus has opted to use a joystick for selecting items on the screen, including spelling of cities and street names. This is awkward and requires much more time than a touch screen would require.

After 4 hours the service writer called and said my vehicle was ready. He explained my radio was hooked up properly. I asked him if this is something Im going to have to live with and he said YES. I was livid!!  I then went to my salesman and shared my experience and he went to his manager who said the would find a solution. My husband drove the vehicle and the radio drove him nuts. He calls and schedules the repair. The service department drove my vehicle, a brand new vehicle and the manager's vehicle and all three dropped signal in the exact same places on the route. They turned the problem over to Lexus engineers and Im still waiting on a solution. (Copied from FCD97): After having the vehicle for three days I took the vehicle to the dealership due to the XM Radio dropping signal. I am a sales representative and I do a lot of driving. I found that the radio is on and off continuely all day long. To the point by the end of the I was a nervous wreck. Four hours later the service department called and told me my vehicle was ready. The service writer told me my radio was hooked up correctly. At that point I asked him ""so your telling me this is something I'm going to have to live with"" his response was yes. I drove around to the sales office found my salesman who told me he wanted me to be happy with my product. I explained I was not happy. He went to his manager and they would find a solution. I've had the vehicle since January 2017 and I have yet to be conZZZted with a solution.

(Copied from AEN97): The system is too slow. It doesn't have enough computing power, and it lacks an LTE connection. When I start up the vehicle, it takes 45 seconds before the navigation system has completed it's boot-up. Since it doesn't respond to any user input until the maps have loaded, I am unable to change the radio station or manipulate other functions until it's completely finished booting up. A better alternative to having it cold boot every time would be to have the system enter into a sleep mode while the vehicle is off and cashe the memory instead. It's very hard to get the car to give me directions somewhere. The system frequently misunderstands the street I've given, even though I try to speak very clearly. For instance, I live in Chicago, and sometimes I'll say a street clearly, and it will repeat back to me the wrong street in a city that is hundreds and hundreds of miles away. You'd think that it would default to places closer to home. Usually, after trying a few times to use the car navigation, I'll just go back to my iPhone and ask IT for directions, because the iphone seems to be programmed with some of those common sense parameters. Another time, I asked the car to send me to the nearest FedEx location. Even though I knew that I was pretty close to a FedEx (I just couldn't find it), it gave me a location four states away.  So I just think the navigation in this car needs some improvements

I have two items I wish to note 1) Chime for passenger seat belt intermittently sounds.   I have not taken this to the dealer for correction, as I know it will not be fixed.   I leased a 2015 ATS, and now a 2018 ATS.   The problem existed also in the 2015 model.   Per the dealer, and additional investigation I completed with a friend who works for XX as an engineer at the proving grounds, I was told that this is a known problem and is not slated for correction/modification.   Basically what happens is if the passenger seat is unoccupied, and you place any small items that has metal  (namely sunglasses or the phone charging cable) on the seat, the sensor activates the chime.   It is an annoying chime that we now just ignore.   Although I will say that I almost did not get another Cadillac because of this, but the AWD availability and XX discount sucked me back in for a 2018 lease.2) Bluetooth connectivity for Spotify. I HATE the MB Navigation! I feel like I wasted $2,100 on this feature. First, the maps are small & difficult to read. The lines are thin & most of the map graphic is not in color.  If you compare the MB maps to Apple or Google Maps, you will see a drastic difference in color and ease of reading the map. Second, the routes it take you on are round-about and out of the way. I drive in the New York area and have had so many instances where the navigation system proposed a strange or indirect route. Third, it doesn't let you select the route you want as you can do if using your phone with Google or Apple maps. It should show you the route in an overview before executing it and give you a choice. Forth, the system talks too much!! It becomes annoying hearing it say too many commands, repeating over & over. I hate that MB forces you to choose between Apple Car Play and this more expensive system in the C class.  I should be able to have BOTH and would be easier with TOUCH SCREEN like XX has! They need to revisit the reasoning behind not offering a touch screen radio because I think they are idiots not having that. The joy stick is annoying.

Steering wheel controls to change the radio stations do not advance through the presets. Instead, they advance to the next station on the frequency (not preset). Steering wheel radio controls in most cars operate such that a quick press of the < or > button advances to the next PRESET station and pressing and holding the < or > button advances to the next station on the FREQUENCY. Jaguar has produced a YouTube video to explain how to use the radio steering wheel controls and explains the standard functionality described above (quick press for next preset vs. press and hold for next station on frequency). See the video at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K-lB9Uyr3NY (at the 0:57 mark). This is clearly a flaw in Jaguar's system design. Escalated the issue to Jaguar dealer and Corporate office; no plans to fix it in the future. Not only is this a poor user experience, it is also a safety issue - no way to change radio station without taking eyes off the road to press the touchscreen (Copied from FCD97): Steering wheel controls to change the radio stations do not advance through the presets. Instead, they advance to the next station on the frequency (not preset). (Copied from DEXP97): The Apple Play has had multiple issues. In addition the car was delivered making a clicking noise. After taking the car to service several times within the first few weeks the problem was discovered. A plastic piece that is part of the front window defrost system melted and was popping when heated. The issue took over a week to resolve once diagnosed.

I seem to have problems entering data to the screen. It's like the system won't recognize it when I make selections with my fingers. It takes several attempts to put in addresses. Also, once when I attempted to put in an address, the system automatically blacked out choices when I attempted to put in an exact address for a destination I was headed to. Also, the navigation system sometimes does not take the easiest or quickest route. Sometimes, I prefer to use the GPS on my cell, but I found out, that since I have the navigation system, when I use the cell to get directions to a location, I can't get the audio to come through the phone. My phone shows the directions on the phone, but no voice directions. Certainly a driver can't be looking at the phone directions while driving the vehicle. There should be a way to easily supersede the vehicle navigation system in order to use the cell phone GPS.

I don't use it very often, but occasionally I try to set a destination using the voice commands. Usually it thinks I'm trying to play music, sometimes it thinks I want to make a phone call. I usually give up at that point. I haven't bothered to try to figure out how to get it to work better for me. The one command that does work is ""Take me home."" That only gets me to my preprogrammed home address, of course. And sometimes I forget that is the correct command and try ""Navigate to home"" and end up making a phone call instead.

This usually works great, but about 5% - 10% of the time the Android Auto in the console does not properly connect to the phone. Several different errors appear to cause this. Sometimes I get a red screen on my phone with a message announcing an ""Android Auto connection"" issue; when I press Exit on that screen the console almost always connects. Sometimes I get the Android Auto display on the smartphone, but I do not get the Android Auto icon on the center console. To clear that problem, I must manually exit Android Auto on the smartphone, disconnect the phone from the USB cable, then reconnect the phone to the USB cable again

The navigation system is archaic.  And, the so-called voice-control is a piece of junk.  Just put in a Garmin-based system, or work with Google, and get rid of voice control for simplicity.  Do not release any technical feature before it is ready.  Customers don't like beta-versions.  Acura will be better served by collaborating with Garmin, Google (Android), and Apple (CarPlay).  It seems that Acura tried hard to make the navigation system and voice-control operation as difficult as possible.  Remember, simplicity and ease of operation will go a long way.  This is probably the best marketing tool, too.  And, most drivers don't use all the available features anyway.  Why not invest in making the operation simpler and easier, and more robust, to attract more drivers?  Otherwise, mechanically speaking, the RDX is excellent.  It is just that its navigation system and voice-control are shamefully behind the times.

I monitor my fuel efficiency as I drive.  If at all possible I try to save fuel as I drive; I want to get excellent fuel efficiency.  I could easily do this with the 2014 MKZ Hybrid gauges and monitoring displays.  I find it difficult to do with the 2017 MKZ Hybrid gauges.  When I think I am getting good fuel efficiency, I sometimes am but there are times when at the end of the driving session, the results reported are poor.  I have not yet mentioned this to the dealer but I expect when I do they will tell me it is my driving that is causing poor fuel efficiency; on my 2014 MKZ Hybrid I could almost monitor good fuel efficiency as I drove down the road and the final result at the end of the driving session always matched what I was observing.  The 2017 MKZ Hybrid does not allow me that satisfaction.

There are two sets of issues. One is that the voice navigation is hard to use-- it frequently fails to recognize a spoken address or POI, and more critically than that, if it either cannot find the correct address/POI or finds multiple possibilities, I have been unable to use voice (or even easily use the touch screen) to exit the voice-based destination selection mode. So I end up driving around with the voice recognition function beeping at me and no navigation to my destination. The second is that the POIs in the system are very slow to recognize and frequently incomplete. The other day I was in New York City, trying to find a store called 'Chocolate Works' in Brooklyn, NY. After entering 'Chocolate Works', it took the system a full two minutes to start return results from places as far as Nebraska, and even then, the correct POI was not found. These two issues have caused me a fair amount of frustration and pushed me to just rely on my smartphone for navigation instead.

Most of my attempts to use voice recognition for navigation functions fail. The required syntax is unknown to me and my guesses are wrong. Try to exit a failed attempt is particularly difficult. The navigation map display is poorly laid out compared to the ubiquituous 'Garmin' system I am used to.  This system doesn't not provide easy understanding of what the next turn/action the driver must take nor what the distance is to that next action.  Also the distance to the next action, when it is displayed, is displayed in different locations on the screen depending on the underlying map -- it should always be in the same location so the driver can instantly find it on the screen with only a momentary glance while driving.  I like to display a list of the next several actions I must take - this system only allows that as a temporary mode.  So, if you have two turns to make in very quick succession this system doesn't tell you anything about the second turn until you complete the first one - leaving you little time to get into the correct lane, etc.

I had On-Star with my 2011.  No real problems.  Three MAJOR problems/concerns with On-Star in the 2017.  #1 - when I get directions to my home address, the location is almost 100 feet off!  I didn't have this problem in the 2011.  #2 - if I pull off of the main route, for whatever reason, I'm told to return to the trip route and the directions will return!!!  I can't go off of the assigned route!!  Traffic may be diverted because of an accident, etc.  I didn't have this problem in the 2011.  On-Star simply computed a new best route. #3 - I can't get the 'route' to display on the screen.  In the 2011 this was very helpful because I could look ahead at crossroads, etc.   Some of the above may be happening because I am still on the free trial of On-Star, although I'm sure I did not have any of these problems before.  Thanks.

Sport mode is ridiculous for a car that's supposed to focus on economy.

I've had difficulty getting the built-in garage door opener in the Lexus to operate properly.  The instructions in the operating manual do not work with my garage door opener.  My Salesman walked me through a process of pairing the car with a handheld garage door opener first and then pairing the Lexus built-in system with the garage door opener in the garage.  This worked initially, but operating the Lexus garage door opener effected the garage door operations of other cars, that we own, that have built-in garage door openers.  I finally purchased a handheld garage door opener for use in the Lexus rather than use the built-in system.
